Review Low-iridium/ruthenium perovskite oxides: An emerging family of material platforms for oxygen evolution reaction in acid Lingjie Yuan Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Zhongliang Dong Formal analysis Zheng Tang Formal analysis Huanhuan Tao Resources Yinlong Zhu Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ Institute for Frontier Science, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Nanjing 210016, Jiangsu, China Institute for Frontier Science Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics Nanjing Jiangsu 210016 China Institute for Frontier Science, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Nanjing 210016, Jiangsu, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This review presents a comprehensive overview of recent advancements in low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides as highly efficient electrocatalysts for acidic OER. Proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer (PEMWE) represents a highly promising technology for renewable hydrogen generation, urgently demanding low-cost, efficient, and robust anode oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalysts in acidic media. Over the past decade (mainly from 2016 onwards), low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides have emerged as promising candidate materials for acidic OER electrocatalysis owing to their flexible element compositions and crystal structures, which can evidently reduce the noble-metal content and meanwhile significantly promote electrocatalytic performance. In this review, the current research progress in low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for acidic OER electrocatalysis is comprehensively summarized. Initially, we present a brief introduction to general issues relevant to acidic OER catalyzed by low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides, such as the actual active species, OER mechanisms, inverse activity-stability relationship, and performance evaluation metrics. Subsequently, we present a thorough overview of various low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for acidic OER electrocatalysis, including single perovskites, double perovskites, triple perovskites, quadruple perovskites, Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites, and other complex perovskite-derived oxides, with emphasis on the intrinsic factors contributing to their exceptional performance and structure–property-performance correlation. Finally, remaining challenges and some promising insights to inspire future studies in this exciting field are provided. Keywords Low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxide Acidic oxygen evolution reaction Optimal use of noble metal Performance promotion Proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer 1 Introduction With the increasing concerns about the rapid depletion of fossil fuel reserves and environmental pollution, it is essential to prioritize the development of sustainable energy from renewable sources, including solar, wind, and geothermal energy [1–3]. Given the intermittent and discontinuous nature of renewable sources, achieving consistent and stable power generation remains a major challenge [4–6]. Converting renewable energy sources into chemical fuels is regarded as a viable and effective strategy for unlocking their full potential applications [7]. In this context, hydrogen (H2) fuel has gained significant attention as a promising energy storage medium by virtue of its high gravimetric energy density (142 MJ kg−1) and zero-carbon nature [8,9]. Electrochemical water splitting, including alkaline water electrolyzers (AWEs), proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWEs), and anion exchange membrane water electrolyzers (AEMWEs), is recognized as one of the most efficient and environmentally friendly methods for H2 production [10–13]. In particular, PEMWEs operating in acidic media have some significant advantages over other electrolyzer technologies, such as pure water usage, high gas purity (>99.99%), high voltage efficiency (70%–80%), high current densities, low ohmic losses, fast system response, compact design, and wide load range, as summarized in Table 1 [14–16]. In PEMWEs, the two half-reactions involved in electrochemical water splitting are the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). However, the anodic OER is the bottleneck for PEMWEs due to the intrinsic sluggish kinetics that involves a multistep proton-coupled electron transfer process (Fig. 1 ) [17–19]. At present, iridium/ruthenium (Ir/Ru)-based noble metal oxides, typical IrO2/RuO2 with favorable activity and stability, are deemed as the benchmark OER electrocatalysts in acid for commercial PEMWEs, but the expensiveness and scarcity of high-content Ir/Ru impede their large-scale practical application [18,20–23]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop alternative low-Ir/Ru-based OER electrocatalysts with high activity and robust durability in acidic media. The design of perovskite oxides offers an effective solution for both reducing the noble metal usage and enhancing electrocatalytic activity [5,24,25]. Compared with other types of Ir/Ru-based compounds, a distinct superiority of perovskite oxides is the variety of the compositions and structures, which offers unusual geometrical, electronic, and conductive characteristics [26,27]. Due to the advantages of low cost, high intrinsic activity, chemical stability, compositional/structural variety, flexible tunability, earth-abundance, and environmental friendliness, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides have received considerable interest for OER in acidic media [23,28–30]. For instance, a pioneering exploration carried out by Seitz et al. prepared pseudo-cubic SrIrO3 thin films on SrTiO3 substrates via pulsed laser deposition, forming IrO x /SrIrO3 with landmark intrinsic OER activity due to Sr leaching from SrIrO3 during acidic OER [23]. Following this research, numerous low-Ir/Ru single perovskite oxides have been investigated in acidic OER [26,31,32]. In addition to single perovskites with the chemical formula ABO3, several subclasses of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides have been investigated as well, including double perovskite oxides (A2B2O6), triple perovskite oxides (A3B3O9), quadruple perovskite oxides (A4B4O12), Ruddlesden-Popper perovskite oxides (A n +1B n O3 n +1; n = 1, 2, and 3), and other complex perovskite-derived oxides [33–39]. On account of significant progress in the last decade (mainly from 2016 onwards) with the timeline of the major accomplishments illustrated in Fig. 2 , low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides have emerged as a promising class of electrocatalysts for acidic OER, which motivates the necessity of reviewing this promising research area. However, there has been no comprehensive summary of this significant topic and few thorough reviews have been published to date. Herein, we present a systematic overview of recent advancements in low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxide electrocatalysts for acidic OER, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . This review is divided into the following sections. Firstly, we briefly introduce some general issues relevant to low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides catalyzing acidic OER, including the real active species, OER mechanisms, inverse activity-stability relationship, and performance evaluation metrics. Following this, the recent advances in low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for acidic OER electrocatalysis, such as single perovskites, double perovskites, triple perovskites, quadruple perovskites, Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites, and other complex perovskite-derived oxides, are comprehensively summarized. In the discussion, particular emphasis is placed on the intrinsic factors contributing to their exceptional performance. Finally, some existing challenges and promising insights to inspire future studies in this emerging field are provided. We believe that this timely review will not only promote a deep understanding of low-Ir/Ru perovskite for acidic OER but also provide some guidelines for advanced catalyst design in the future. 2 General issues relevant to acidic OER catalyzed by low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides In order to reduce the content of Ir/Ru in the OER electrocatalysts, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides have been widely investigated. Many perovskite oxides (e.g., SrIrO3, Sr2CaIrO6, and CaCu3Ru4O12) exhibit superior performance compared to IrO2/RuO2 for OER under acidic media [32,40,41]. However, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides are prone to surface reconstruction during acidic OER, where A-site cation dissolution under the oxidative conditions leads to the formation of IrO x or RuO x as the actual active species rather than the original structure of perovskite oxides [42,43]. The dissolution and reconstruction on the electrocatalyst surface present a series of issues regarding the electrocatalytic active species, electrocatalytic mechanisms, inverse activity-stability relation, and performance evaluation metrics (Fig. 4 ). 2.1 Electrocatalytic active species Identifying and understanding the active species involved in the OER is crucial for designing highly efficient electrocatalysts. However, capturing transient active species and monitoring dynamic surface reconstruction in liquid electrolytes remain significant challenges [44–46]. Low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides, such as SrIrO3, are prone to undergo surface reconstruction during acidic OER, where the dissolution of Sr under operational conditions results in the formation of IrO x as the actual active species [23]. Following this pioneering work, research into the true active species of low-Ir perovskite oxides has gained more interest [47–50]. For example, SrCo0.9Ir0.1O3 − δ undergoes surface reconstruction during electrochemical processes, accompanied by substantial leaching of Sr and Co [50]. However, it maintains high activity and durability due to the formation of corner-shared and under-coordinated IrO x octahedra, which serve as the true active species providing more active sites for the OER. Generally, Ir-oxy/hydroxide is recognized as the main active species for high electrocatalytic OER activity in low-Ir perovskite oxides [51,52]. Compared to low-Ir perovskite oxides, low-Ru perovskite oxides typically exhibit higher catalytic activity but lower stability, primarily due to the dissolution of Ru into highly soluble active species such as soluble RuO5 2− or volatile RuO4 at high voltages (>1.3–1.4 V) [53–55]. Therefore, weak stability of low-Ru perovskite oxides seems to be associated with the conversion of Ru4+ to Ru>4+ under high-voltage conditions [56]. Surface reconstruction commonly occurs in low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides during acidic OER, and the reconstructed species are often regarded as the true active sites [55,57]. Notably, the surface reconstruction degree of electrocatalysts is highly influenced by the applied OER potential, which typically encompasses a broader voltage range than the redox potential range of the catalysts [52]. During anodic polarization, metal cations on the electrocatalyst surface usually transfer from a lower oxidation state to a higher oxidation state, which has been extensively recognized as the true active species during acidic OER [58]. Various electrocatalytic conditions (e.g. temperature, pressure, and pH) can affect the redox kinetics and potentials, leading to the formation of diverse oxide products [59]. Besides the external factors, the structural characteristics of electrocatalysts, such as the covalency of the metal–oxygen bonds and structural defects, also play crucial roles in surface reconstruction [8]. It has been experimentally demonstrated that the high concentration of structural defects can facilitate surface reconstruction, thereby promoting the formation of high-valence metal active species [60]. In addition, the lattice oxygen evolution reaction, which occurs through the lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) pathway, may contribute to the surface reconstruction of electrocatalysts with high covalency of metal–oxygen bonds as well [58]. The complex mechanisms of the reconstruction hinder the identification and characterization of the true active species [61,62]. Recent advancements in in-situ/operando characterization techniques have enabled the monitoring of active species and reaction intermediates during dynamic reconstruction. As listed in Table 2 , current in-situ/operando characterization techniques including Raman spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS), scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM), hard X-ray absorption spectroscopy (hXAS), and Mӧssbauer spectroscopy are employed to uncover the processes of dynamic reconstruction [63]. Nevertheless, these techniques still encounter significant limitations in achieving high spatial and temporal resolution under real catalytic conditions, preventing the capture of rapid structural reconstructions on the picosecond to nanosecond timescale [64,65]. Therefore, future research should focus on developing more advanced in-situ/operando characterization techniques and integrating multiple in-situ/operando techniques to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the reconstruction process and the evolution of true active species. 2.2 Electrocatalytic mechanisms Understanding the mechanisms of OER is essential for guiding the rational design of effective electrocatalysts. Several mechanisms have been proposed, with the most widely accepted being the conventional adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) [62,66,67], the LOM [68,69], and oxide path mechanism (OPM) [70–72], which will be stated concisely as follows. Adsorption evolution mechanism (AEM). The AEM involves four proton-coupled electron transfer steps, with all the oxygen atoms in the generated O2 molecules originating from adsorbed species (OH−/H2O) (Fig. 5 a) [66,73,74]. Initially, water molecules (H2O) are adsorbed onto the catalyst’s active surface sites, forming an M-OH intermediate (HO*) and releasing a proton (H+) along with an electron (e−). Subsequently, one proton and one electron are released from HO*, forming an O* intermediate. Then, another H2O molecule nucleophilically attacks the O*, generating the HOO* intermediate while releasing a proton and an electron. Finally, one electron is transferred from HOO* to the metal M cation, releasing O2 and regenerating the catalyst’s active site [67]. Clearly, each step involves proton-electron coupling transfer, resulting in pH-independent OER activity. In the AEM pathway, the proton release from HO* to form O* and the transformation of O* to HOO* are always the rate-determining steps (RDS) [67,74]. The oxygen-containing intermediates are adsorbed on the electrocatalyst surface via oxygen atoms, leading to a linear relationship between the binding energy of HO* and HOO* (i.e., ΔG HOO*−ΔG HO* = 3.2 ± 0.2 eV). If the formation of HOO* requires a higher energy barrier, the formation of HO* correspondingly exhibits a lower energy barrier, and vice versa [75]. Therefore, an ideal electrocatalytic OER reaction exhibits the binding energy of 1.6 eV in the ΔG O*−ΔG HO*, which provides a minimum overpotential of 370 mV in theory [76]. Lattice oxygen-evolution mechanism (LOM). In the LOM process, O2 molecules are released with the participation of lattice oxygen in the electrocatalysts, involving non-concerted proton-electron transfer and lattice-oxygen oxidation [69,77]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), an oxygen atom bound to the metal site directly migrates into the adsorbed O* intermediate, forming O–O bonds and facilitating the release of lattice oxygen through the generation of surface oxygen vacancies [78]. In a typical density functional theory (DFT) calculation of the LOM pathway, the OH* intermediate deprotonates at the lattice oxygen site to produce OO*, which creates the VO followed by the release of O2 molecules [76]. Unlike the AEM pathway, the LOM pathway does not involve the formation of HOO* intermediates, thereby effectively overcoming the overpotential limitations observed in the AEM process [20,78]. Notably, the involvement of lattice oxygen in acidic OER is induced by the strong covalency of the metal–oxygen bond, which can facilitate the formation of ligand holes and shift the electroactive sites from metal to O sites [79]. Although the LOM generally exhibits higher activity than the AEM, careful attention should be paid to the position and reversible filling of lattice oxygen. Slow oxygen vacancy refilling during subsequent electrocatalytic cycles will lead to severe metal dissolution and structural collapse [68,80,81]. Oxide path mechanism (OPM). The OPM involves the direct coupling of two *Os originating from absorbed OH− or H2O without the formation of extra reaction intermediates (*OOH) or oxygen vacancies, which effectively maintains the thermally stable structure and overcomes the scaling relationship limitation [71,82,83]. Specifically, *OH is formed at two adjacent sites on the catalyst surface through successive deprotonation, generating two *O intermediates that couple directly to produce O2 molecules (Fig. 5c) [82]. However, OPM imposes stricter requirements on the geometric arrangement of active metal sites compared to AEM and LOM [70,75,84]. Consequently, symmetric bimetallic sites with optimal atomic spacing (neither too long nor too short) are expected to facilitate the binding of O–O at low potentials. Other mechanisms. In addition to three common mechanisms as discussed above, several specialized mechanisms for specific systems have been also proposed, such as the coupled oxygen evolution mechanism (COM) [85], peroxide-ion participation mechanism (POM) [39], and dual-metal-site mechanism (DMSM) [86–88]. The COM mechanism follows an optimized electron transfer pathway where electrons transfer along the lowest available energy route, with the protonation taking place at the metal bands and O–O coupling occurring at the oxygen state [85]. Besides, a low-Ir complex oxide La1.2Sr2.7IrO7.33 composed of isolated Ir(V)O6 octahedra and peroxide ions (O2 2−) was reported to follow an unusual peroxide-ion participation mechanism (POM) for acidic OER [39]. Furthermore, the dual metal site mechanism (DMSM) could minimize the free energy barrier of the RDS compared to the single-metal-site mechanism (SMSM) and AEM [86,87]. In the DMSM, two metal atoms act as active sites and cooperate in the OER, which can facilitate efficient electron and proton transfer between two metal atoms. The dual-site configuration promotes the intra-molecular coupling of activated lattice oxygen, forming an M–OlatOlat–M structure where the –OlatOlat– bond eventually detaches from the lattice [88]. 2.3 Inverse activity-stability correlation In acidic OER, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides typically exhibit an inverse relation between activity and stability [89]. Higher catalytic activity generally correlates with lower structural stability, representing a major challenge in the electrocatalyst design [57]. For example, amorphous IrO x exhibits higher catalytic activity but lower structural stability than crystalline IrO2 [90]. Two mechanisms have been proposed to explain the inverse relationship between activity and stability [91,92]. The first is the lattice oxygen mechanism, in which the involvement of lattice oxygen significantly enhances the catalytic activity but leads to the formation of surface oxygen vacancies [91]. The surface vacancies are often filled by the oxygen atoms migrating from the bulk to the surface, which results in a deeper amorphous layer and causes structural instability [93]. Another explanation is that, under anodic potentials, Ir/Ru can be further oxidized to higher valence states, which act as active sites. However, these higher-valence species tend to dissolve in the electrolyte, thereby reducing the catalyst stability [46,58,92]. The inverse relationship between activity and stability remains a critical issue that limits the development of acidic OER electrocatalysts, requiring new strategies to overcome this challenge. 2.4 Performance evaluation metrics To evaluate the OER catalytic performance of a given electrocatalyst, several important metric parameters need to be measured or calculated, including overpotential, Tafel slope, turnover frequency, mass activity, specific activity, and stability, as summarized in Table 3 [94]. A thorough understanding of these parameters is essential for designing an efficient electrocatalyst. In this section, we briefly discuss the physicochemical meaning and interpretation of these parameters and more details can be found in several previous reviews [26,94–96]. In acidic OER, the activity of electrocatalysts is typically assessed with metrics such as overpotential (η), Tafel slope, turnover frequency (TOF), mass activities, and specific activities [96]. The overpotential is a crucial parameter to evaluate the activity of catalysts, which indicates the additional potential required beyond the theoretical voltage of 1.23 V. Typically, the η value is calculated at a fixed current density normalized with different methods, such as 10 mA cm−2 geo, 10 mA mg−1, or 10 mA cm−2 ECSA/BET, where a lower value represents higher activity [97,98]. The mass activity which is normalized by the mass loading is significant for practical applications. In particular, the comparison of mass activity is of great significance for Ir/Ru-based electrocatalysts. To evaluate the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalysts, specific activity is typically normalized by electrochemical surface area (ECSA) or Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area [95]. The Tafel slope is another representative parameter to assess the kinetic activity of catalysts, which can be derived from the steady-state measurements or Tafel equation [99]. Additionally, TOF is an important kinetic parameter that describes the number of reactants converted to O2 per catalytic site per unit time, reflecting the intrinsic activity of catalytic sites [5]. Typically, high-performance OER electrocatalysts exhibit a higher TOF and lower Tafel slope. Besides OER activity, long-term stability is another critical factor in assessing the feasibility of electrocatalysts for practical PEM applications. Generally, two common methods are used to evaluate long-term stability: chronopotentiometry/chronoamperometry tests and thousands of cyclic voltammetry scans [94]. Considering that these evaluation metrics can be influenced by some experimental conditions (e.g., mass loading, ink preparation, electrolyte, and conductive substrate), different electrocatalysts in one work should be measured under the same experimental conditions for a fair performance comparison. As a successful example, Geiger et al. proposed a new metric (i.e., S-number) to evaluate the catalytic stability for OER under acidic conditions, which is defined as the ratio between the amount of evolved oxygen and the amount of dissolved Ir [100]. Consequently, the S-number is independent of surface area, mass loading, or involved active sites, providing a convincing metric to compare the stability of different electrocatalysts. 3 Recent development of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for OER in acidic media Low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides have emerged as promising candidate materials for OER under acidic media. According to the features of the structure, the low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxide-based OER electrocatalysts can be categorized into single perovskites, double perovskites, triple perovskites, quadruple perovskites, Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites, and other complex perovskite-derived oxides (Fig. 6 ). In the following part, recent advancements in low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides as efficient electrocatalysts for acidic OER are comprehensively reviewed and some illustrative studies are discussed emphatically. In addition, the structure-property-performance relationship and design strategies for low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxide electrocatalysts will be emphasized as well. 3.1 Single perovskite oxides Single perovskites with the general formula ABO3 are considered the simplest type of perovskite structure, consisting of A-site and B-site cations coordinated with oxygen atoms, forming a three-dimensional network [101]. The A-site cation occupies the lattice corners with 12-fold coordination, forming a structure of cuboctahedron, while the B-site cation is situated at the center of the [BO6] octahedron with 6-fold coordination [102]. SrIrO3 and SrRuO3 are widely recognized as the most representative low-Ir/Ru single perovskite oxide electrocatalysts, demonstrating significant potential for OER in acidic media [23,31,103]. In 2016, Seitz and co-workers pioneered the use of AIrO3 single perovskite oxides as electrocatalysts for acidic OER [23]. They reported a stable and active IrO x /SrIrO3 catalyst, which was formed through the leaching of Ir from the pseudocubic SrIrO3 thin films during electrochemical testing. The IrO x /SrIrO3 exhibits excellent OER activity and stability, demonstrating an overpotential in the range of 270–290 mV for 30 h. Based on DFT calculations, the superior performance is attributed to the formation of anatase IrO2 or IrO3 motifs on the surface, which contributes to its enhanced catalytic efficiency (Fig. 7 a and b). Furthermore, Song et al. employed atomic column-resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy to observe the surface reconstruction of AIrO3 (A = Sr or Ba) perovskite oxides during acidic OER [103]. In this regard, they synthesized three types of AIrO3 oxides: pseudocubic SrIrO3 thin films grown on (LaAlO3)0.3(SrAl0.5Ta0.5O3)0.7 substrates using a reactive-oxide molecular-beam epitaxy method, and monoclinic SrIrO3 and BaIrO3 prepared via a conventional solid-state method. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images reveal that all AIrO3 perovskite oxides exhibit surface reconstruction and surface roughening due to the leaching of Sr or Ba during the OER in acidic media. Rapid leaching of Sr from pseudocubic SrIrO3 films leads to the formation of rutile IrO2 on the surface and gradually transforms into amorphous IrO x , which plays a crucial role in enhancing OER activity (Fig. 7c). In contrast, amorphous IrO x is directly formed on the surface of monoclinic SrIrO3 and BaIrO3 during the OER test, without the formation of nanocrystals (Fig. 7d and e). In recent studies, numerous AIrO3 electrocatalysts for OER have been developed via various strategies such as ion doping, morphology engineering, and heterojunction modulation, which facilitate the modification of their electronic structure and the enhancement of their performance, as will be discussed below. 3.1.1 Ion doping Doping is an effective strategy to reduce noble-metal usage and enhance the OER performance of electrocatalysts, which can modulate the electronic structure of the original active sites and create new active sites [50,104–111]. For example, Huang et al. incorporated trace Pt into SrIrO3, effectively reducing the OER energy barrier and mitigating Ir overoxidation [107]. However, despite the enhanced activity and stability, the cost efficiency of noble-metal Pt doping remains limited. Chen et al. designed a pseudocubic Co-doped SrIrO3 (SrCo0.9Ir0.1O3− δ ) containing corner-sharing IrO6 octahedra, which exhibits extremely high catalytic intrinsic catalytic due to the formation of surface amorphous IrO x H y during acidic OER (Fig. 8 a) [50]. In the following study, Chen and coworkers further optimized B-site doping in SrIrO3 to manipulate the leaching of A-site and B-site metals, thereby controlling the surface reconstruction of the electrocatalyst (Fig. 8b) [111]. To this end, they synthesized SrSc0.5Ir0.5O3 and SrCo0.5Ir0.5O3 through solid-state methods, enabling a step-by-step evaluation of their catalytic and structural evolution. During the OER process, Sr leaching enhances the electrochemical surface area by forming a honeycomb-like structure, while Sc/Co leaching facilitates the formation of highly active IrO x H y (Fig. 8c). Dual-site leaching induces dynamic reconstruction of the electrocatalysts, resulting in intrinsic activity two orders of magnitude higher than that of rutile-type IrO2 (Fig. 8d). Recently, Zhao et al. also doped Co into SrIrO3 and proposed the lattice-oxygen promoted adsorbate evolution mechanism (LOPAEM) to explain the enhanced OER activity in acidic media (Fig. 8e) [110]. They found that higher Co content promotes the LOM, while the AEM remains the dominant pathway (Fig. 8f and g). They proposed that LOM induces Co dissolution and facilitates the formation of low coordination, unsaturated IrO x species (Fig. 8h and i), which increases the number of active sites and improves the efficiency of AEM. Through transition metal doping, Liang et al. proposed an innovative perovskite solid-solution alloying strategy by introducing Zr into SrIrO3, effectively breaking the inverse relation between activity and stability while significantly reducing catalyst costs [108]. Besides metal doping, non-metal doping can also modulate the electronic structure of SrIrO3 and enhance its OER catalytic performance [75,112,113]. A representative study is from the You's group, who investigated S-doped SrIrO3 nanosheets and demonstrated that S incorporation can modulate the electronic structure of the catalyst [75]. During the OER process, Sr leaching from the surface results in the formation of an Ir(O, S) x amorphous layer, which plays a crucial role in enhancing the catalytic performance. Not limited to non-metal doping in SrIrO3, the introduction of Ir into non-precious perovskite oxides can reduce the Ir content and enhance electrocatalytic performance as well [113–116]. For instance, Zou et al. first reported the incorporation of Ir into SrTiO3 to activate inert Ti sites and enhance its catalytic activity, with SrTi0.67Ir0.33O3 successfully synthesized via the polymerized complex method (Fig. 9 a) [116]. Compared to the benchmark electrocatalyst IrO2, SrTi0.67Ir0.33O3 with 57 wt% less Ir exhibits more than 10 times higher electrocatalytic OER activity while maintaining the original crystal structure during the OER test (Fig. 9b and c). Later, the same group expanded the study of Ir-doped systems by synthesizing a class of 66 SrTi x Ru y Ir z O3 perovskite oxides with various atomic ratios of Ti, Ir, and Ru (Fig. 9d) [114]. XAS reveals that optimal hybridization between B–O bonds is essential for balancing the catalytic activity and structural stability (Fig. 9e and f). Based on systematic experiments and theoretical calculations, the positive linear relationship between activity and B–O bond covalency in SrTi x Ru y Ir z O3 perovskite oxides can be interpreted (Fig. 9g and h). Enhanced B–O bond covalency, when kept within a reasonable range, can effectively lower the energy barrier for the formation of the O–O bond, which is identified as a critical step in AEM [117]. However, excessive B–O bond covalency induces electron transfer from the O 2p state to the B nd state, leading to the formation of activated lattice oxygen. To date, Ru-based perovskite oxides have been rarely reported as an effective electrocatalyst for acidic OER, primarily because the high dissolution of Ru compromises their stability [55]. Although SrRuO3 demonstrates high catalytic activity under electrochemical conditions, its thermodynamic instability significantly limits its applicability in OER processes [31]. To improve the OER catalytic activity and stability of SrRuO3 in acidic environments, doping A-site with low-valence cations is regarded as an effective strategy [112,118,119]. For example, Retuerto et al. introduced Na into SrRuO3, which induces a higher oxidation state of Ru (Fig. 10 a), thereby positively shifting Ru d-band centers and O p-band centers and weakening the bond between Ru and reaction intermediates to promote OER activity (Fig. 10b and c) [118]. Additionally, the enhanced stability of Sr0.9Na0.1RuO3, which is attributed to the Ru centers with lower surface energy, higher oxidation states, higher dissolution potentials, and less distorted RuO6 octahedra, is more significant. As demonstrated in Fig. 10(d), Sr0.9Na0.1RuO3 retains 85% of its initial activity after 20 cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycles, whereas the electrochemical activity of undoped SrRuO3 degrades almost completely. Moreover, a comparison of the structural evolution after 20 cycles reveals that the crystal structure and elemental composition of Sr0.9Na0.1RuO3 do not exhibit significant degradation, while SrRuO3 undergoes substantial structural deterioration (Fig. 10e and f). The authors proposed that the shortened Ru–O bond distance and regular octahedral configuration induced by Na doping are key factors contributing to enhanced structural stability (Fig. 10g and h). Subsequently, K+ doping has been also reported to enhance the stability of SrRuO3 under acidic OER conditions by reducing structural distortion and improving the durability of the catalyst (Fig. 10i) [119]. These studies demonstrate that A-site doping with low-valence cations, such as Na+ and K+, which can be easily incorporated into the octahedral voids formed by six O2− ions, can significantly enhance the OER activity and stability of SrRuO3 in acidic environments. 3.1.2 Morphology engineering Developing low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides with specific morphologies, such as nanowires, nanosheets, and nanostructured frameworks, provides an effective approach to optimize their electronic structures and increase active sites, thereby significantly enhancing their catalytic activity [120,121]. In recent years, significant attention has been focused on the morphology engineering of SrIrO3, resulting in remarkable advancements [122–124]. For example, Shin et al. synthesized SrIrO3 nanofibers via the electrospinning method, which exhibits extremely low overpotentials across broad pH ranges [122]. Yang et al. synthesized ultrathin two-dimensional (2D) SrIrO3 nanosheets (2D-SIO) with a thickness of 5 nm and a specific surface area of 57.6 m2 g−1 (Fig. 11 a), which is significantly higher than that of SrIrO3 prepared by traditional solid-state method [123]. Theoretical calculations further reveal that the exposed (001) crystal facets of the nanosheets play a crucial role inthe OER process, which enhances the deprotonation ability of the electrocatalyst, promoting the formation of intermediates O* and accelerating O–O bond formation. As shown in Fig. 11(b), the authors calculated surface phase diagrams for 2D-SIO and IrO2 to explore the enhanced deprotonation capability of 2D-SIO. At low potentials, both surfaces are OH/H2O-terminated, whereas the Ir sites are covered with O* at higher potentials, indicating the occurrence of deprotonation. Notably, 2D-SIO requires a lower potential (1.35 V) than IrO2 (1.41 V) to facilitate O* formation. Theoretical calculations indicate that lattice oxygen on the (001) surface plays a limited role in the OER process, with the reaction mainly occurring via the AEM (Fig. 11c). In acidic media, SrIrO3 nanosheets exhibit superior activity with an overpotential of 243 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and maintain the OER activity for 5000 continuous CV cycles (Fig. 11d). Nevertheless, Sr leaching remains a major challenge during prolonged catalysis, limiting the practical application of these electrocatalysts [26,124]. Afterward, You et al. proposed an anion engineering strategy by introducing S to further modulate the electronic structure of SrIrO3 nanosheets [124]. The incorporation of S can generate oxygen vacancies, reducing the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates and thereby enhancing catalytic performance (Fig. 11e and f). Moreover, Sr leaching facilitates the formation of an Ir(O, S) x amorphous layer, which can contribute to the improvement of the catalytic activity and stability in acidic environments. 3.1.3 Heterojunction modulation In addition to the strategies mentioned above, heterojunction modulation which modifies the electronic structures and accelerates electron transfer by balancing the adsorption and desorption energies, demonstrates great benefits in enhancing the electrocatalytic OER performance [7,125,126]. For example, You et al. proposed a 0D/2D heterostructure of 4CeO2@SrIrO3, which consists of CeO2 quantum dots decorated on SrIrO3 nanosheets, exhibiting an ultralow overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 of 238 mV and superior durability for 50 h in 0.5 M H2SO4 (Fig. 11g) [126]. Theoretical calculations reveal that CeO2 modification redistributes the charge at the interface, which alters the adsorption behavior of reaction intermediates and ultimately lowers the theoretical OER energy barrier. Moreover, the heterostructure can effectively mitigate Sr leaching, ensuring the long-term structural stability of 4CeO2@SrIrO3. 3.2 Double perovskite oxides Double perovskite oxides are a common subclass of perovskite oxides, characterized by cation ordering which have the chemical formulas of AA′B2O6 or A2BB′O6 [127]. For double perovskite oxides, the most common structures are A-site layered ordering and B-site rock-salt ordering, which can lead to more complex atomic environments and electronic structures that are unattainable in single perovskites [54,128,129]. Therefore, double perovskite oxides can offer some unique advantages, such as tunable ionic defects, high electrical conductivity, and fast oxygen-ion exchange for electrocatalytic applications [128,130,131]. Some double perovskite oxide electrocatalysts with excellent performance have been developed for acidic OER, but there were no reports on A-site cation-ordered low-Ir/Ru double perovskite oxides for acidic OER. Therefore, the following discussion will focus on double perovskites with B-site cation ordering. In 2016, Diaz-Morales et al. reported a class of Ir-based double perovskites (i.e., Ba2MIrO6; M = Y, La, Ce, Pr, Nd, and Tb) as OER electrocatalysts, which exhibit more than threefold higher intrinsic activity than IrO2 in acidic media while containing 32 wt% less Ir (Fig. 12 a and b) [33]. Based on the research of Ba2PrIrO6, Geiger and his team demonstrated that the lattice oxygen atom can trigger the dissolution of non-noble elements and the enhancement of catalytic activity [100]. Besides, they introduced a new metric (i.e., the S-number) to evaluate the catalytic stability in acidic media, which is independent of surface area, loading, or active sites, providing a deeper understanding of the degradation mechanisms (Fig. 12c). Grimaud and coworkers also emphasized the role of lattice-oxygen in acidic OER and demonstrated that the high activity of La2LiIrO6 arises from the surface lattice-oxygen sites with acting as electrophilic centers [54]. With the help of TEM, they observed the drastic surface reconstruction of La2LiIrO6, where Ir migrates from the bulk to the surface (Fig. 12d). Later, the same group investigated the behavior of Sr2MIr(V)O6 (M = Fe, Co) as OER catalysts in acidic media, whose activities are roughly equal to La2LiIrO6 or Ba2PrIrO6 [132]. They conducted electrochemical measurements focusing on the studies of the Ir dissolution and proposed a dissolution-electrodeposition/precipitation OER mechanism for these low-Ir double perovskites (Fig. 12e). Retuerto et al. further optimized the B-site cation and prepared the Sr2CaIrO6 perovskite, which exhibits excellent activity and stability [40]. They demonstrated that the dissolution of Sr and Ca does not cause the collapse of the perovskite structure, which is attributed to the large ionic radius of Ca2+ that can facilitate the rapid dissolution of Ca ions and allow H3O+ molecules to fill the voids (Fig. 12f). However in another study, Zou and coworkers discovered that Ir-based double perovskite oxides (A2B′IrO6) undergo instant dissolution upon contact with the acidic electrolyte under non-catalytic conditions, which is associated with the leaching of B′-sites (Fig. 12g) [133]. Taking six typical Ir-based double perovskites as model electrocatalysts, Ir leaching does not occur in Sr2TiIrO6, which has a stable structural framework, whereas in all other samples, the A and B′ elements are prone to severe leaching (Fig. 12h and i). This work indicates that the Ir-leaching process of double perovskite-based electrocatalysts in the acidic OER is determined by the stability of the structural framework, guiding the rational design of low-Ir perovskite oxides. Additionally, adjusting the radius and oxidation state of A-site cations to optimize the OER performance of low-Ir/Ru double perovskite oxides is another promising approach [127,129,134]. For this case, Ganguly and his colleagues synthesized double perovskites A2CoIrO6 using a range of lanthanide and non-lanthanide elements (A = Sr, Nd, Sm, and Y) [127]. They found that NdCoIrO6 exhibits the best OER activity, as its d-band center is closest to the Fermi level. Similar to Ir-based double perovskites, A-site tuning is also critical in Ru-based perovskite oxides. Rojas et al. synthesized a series of low-Ru content B-site ordered double perovskites R2NiRuO6 (R = Pr, Nd, Tb, Dy, Y, Ho, and Er) [129]. Experimental results reveal that Dy2NiRuO6 exhibits the best OER performance, which is largely attributed to its shorter Ru–O bond that favors the progression of the OER reaction. 3.3 Triple perovskite oxides Triple perovskites with the general formula A3B3O9− δ have a structure derived from cubic perovskites, which is formed by stacking three single perovskite units with the c-axis three times longer than the other axes [135]. Although some low-Ir/Ru triple perovskite oxides have been successfully synthesized, their application in acidic OER remains limited. One typical study was reported by the Zou group, who synthesized a class of triple perovskite electrocatalysts with the formula Ba3M′M″2O9 (M′ = Ti, In, or Zn; M″2 = IrIr, IrTi, IrRu, RuRu), which consists of two subunits interacted synergistically through corner-sharing M″2O9 octahedral dimers and single M′O6 octahedra (Fig. 13 a) [136]. Experimental results and theoretical calculations demonstrate that the synergistic effect between the surface-shared Ir2O9 octahedral dimers and M′O6 octahedra plays an important role in modulating the metal–oxygen covalent bond and optimizing the O 2p-band center, enabling efficient OER electrocatalysis (Fig. 13b and c). Ultimately, they identified an excellent triple perovskite oxide Ba3TiIr2O9 as a highly active low-iridium electrocatalyst for OER in acid, which exhibits more than 28 times higher intrinsic activity than IrO2 but contains 47 wt% less Ir (Fig. 13d). Furthermore, the same group also reported lanthanide-based triple perovskites, Ba3LnIr2O9 (Ln = lanthanides), with Ba3LaIr2O9 identified as the most active catalyst due to its optimal O 2p-band properties (Fig. 13e) [137]. These studies provide valuable insights into the relationship between structure and property, guiding the rational design of low-Ir OER electrocatalysts. Similar to Ir-based triple perovskite oxides, Ru-based triple perovskites also show great potential in reducing noble metal content and enhancing intrinsic catalytic activity. Recently, Wu et al. synthesized a Ru-based triple perovskite oxide Sr2CaRu2IrO9, which exhibits exceptional acidic OER performance with an ultra-low overpotential of only 172 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and maintains its activity for 75 h (Fig. 13f and g) [34]. Experimental and theoretical results indicate that the introduction of Ca and Ir dual-sites can shift the O 2p and Ru 4d-band centers far from the Fermi level, which weakens the Ru–O covalent bond and enhances the electrocatalytic OER activity (Fig. 13h). Moreover, the weakened Ru–O covalent bond reduces the excessive generation of oxygen vacancies during acidic OER, balancing the functions of AEM and LOM and preventing structural collapse (Fig. 13i). 3.4 Quadruple perovskite oxides Quadruple perovskite oxides with the formula of AA′3B4O12 exhibit 1:3-type ordering of A-site cation, where one-quarter of the A-sites is occupied by conventional A-site cations in icosahedral coordination, while the remaining three-quarters are taken up by transition metals in pseudo-square planar coordination [138]. The complex crystal structure of quadruple perovskite oxides provides multiple metal sites that act as active centers for OER, thereby enhancing the intrinsic activity and stability of electrocatalysts in acidic OER [41,139–141]. Recently, quadruple perovskite oxides with Ru/Ir at the B-site have received more attention for acidic OER catalysis. For example, Hu et al. for the first time reported a low-Ru quadruple perovskite oxide CaCu3Ru4O12 with an ultralow overpotential of 171 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which is much lower than that of benchmark RuO2 (Fig. 14 a and b) [41]. Notably, CaCu3Ru4O12 exhibits a mass activity two orders of magnitude higher than that of RuO2, significantly reducing the usage of precious Ru. DFT calculations indicate that the low Ru 4d band center of quadruple perovskite oxide CaCu3Ru4O12 optimizes the absorption energy of the reaction intermediates and accelerates reaction kinetics, leading to the enhancement of catalytic activity (Fig. 14c and d). Although the above-mentioned study demonstrates the great potential of CaCu3Ru4O12 as an acidic OER electrocatalyst, the effect of A-site cations on OER performance is still unclear. Therefore, Liu and coworkers prepared a series of ACu3Ru4O12 (A = Ca, Sr, La, Nd, and Ce) to investigate the effect of different A-site cations on the OER performance (Fig. 14e) [141]. They found that different types of A-site cations can modify the average valence states of Cu and Ru, and a volcano relation between activity and the average Cu valence state that associates with the charge transfer effect was found (Fig. 14f). Moreover, the OER stability increases with the decrease of Ru–O bond length, and the shortest Ru–O bond length in CaCu3Ru4O12 contributes to the highest catalytic stability (Fig. 14g). Similar to Ru-based quadruple perovskites, Ir-based quadruple perovskites share similar crystal structures. Recently, Thao et al. introduced Ir ions into CaCu3Ti4O12 (CCTO) as a superior OER electrocatalyst (Fig. 14h), showing a mass activity of 1000 A gIr −1, which is 66 times higher than that of IrO2 [140]. They found that Ir doping in CCTO facilitates the electron transfer from Ti and oxygen vacancies to Ir, creating electron-deficient Ti sites and electron-rich Ir sites which can optimize the adsorption energy of oxygen reaction intermediates (Fig. 14i and j). In short, the above-mentioned studies demonstrate the significance of introducing Ir/Ru into the crystal structure of quadruple perovskite oxide to maximize the mass activity of noble metals. 3.5 Ruddlesden-Popper perovskite oxides Ruddlesden-Popper (RP)-type perovskite oxides, with the general chemical formula A n +1B n O3 n+ 1 or AO(ABO3± δ ) n , have a layered structure composed of n consecutive ABO3-type perovskite layers sandwiched between two AO rock-salt layers along the c-axis [26,142,143]. RP phases typically consist of single (n = 1), double (n = 2), and triple (n = 3) perovskite layers. When n approaches infinity (n = ∞), the structure matches the simple perovskite oxides ABO3 [144]. Currently, RP-type perovskite oxides are the most extensively studied class within perovskite oxides, primarily due to their flexible chemical composition, layered structure, and elemental adaptability [142,143]. In this section, some representative work on low-Ir/Ru-based RP-type perovskite oxides for acidic OER will be elaborated. Wu et al. studied two types of perovskite oxides, Ca2IrO4 and CaIrO3, and found that Ca2IrO4 exhibits superior OER catalytic activity compared to the benchmark catalyst IrO2 in 0.1 M HClO4 [145]. The authors attribute the excellent performance of Ca2IrO4 to its distorted IrO6 octahedral structure, which enhances the interaction between active sites and reaction intermediates. Further, Li et al. prepared Ca2− x IrO4 nanocrystals and investigated their OER performance in different acidic electrolytes [36]. They found that the surface of Ca2− x IrO4 exhibits significant amorphization in H2SO4, while the amorphization phenomenon is not obvious in HClO4 (Fig. 15 a and b). X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra indicate that some CaSO4 molecules are adsorbed on the surface of Ca2− x IrO4 in 0.5 M H2SO4 due to the strong interaction between SO4 2− and the surface of Ca2− x IrO4, possibly resulting in high intrinsic activity but low structural stability (Fig. 15c and d). Later, the same group used operando characterization to directly observe Ir6+=O and Ir6+OO– intermediates, which are stable from 1.3 V vs. RHE in 1 M HClO4 electrolyte [146]. This discovery provides direct evidence for the understanding of the active sites and reaction mechanisms of Ca2− x IrO4 in acidic OER. Continuous research by Li and his colleagues clarifies the impact of electrolyte anions on the long-term stability of acidic OER and deepens the understanding of the OER mechanism of Ca2− x IrO4 through operando methods [36,146]. Sr2IrO4 is a two-dimensional spin-orbit Mott insulator with a layered structure similar to Ca2IrO4 [147]. Strickler and his colleagues explored the influence of different crystal structures on electrocatalytic OER performance under acidic conditions and demonstrated that the RP-type perovskite oxide Sr2IrO4 exhibits excellent intrinsic activity (Fig. 15e) [48]. Taking advantage of the weak interlayer interactions in the layered perovskite structure of Sr2IrO4, protonated colloidal nanosheets with high activity and stability have been successfully prepared through the exfoliation method [143,148]. Zhang and colleagues reported the protonation process of Sr2IrO4 and synthesized a new protonated phase H3.6IrO4·3.7H2O via Sr2+ and H+ cation exchange (Fig. 15f), which features a unique apex-linked IrO6 octahedral layered structure and exhibits excellent performance in acidic OER [148]. Following this work, Zou et al. further optimized the exfoliation method to synthesize layered iridate nanosheets (HION) [143]. These nanosheets retain the layered perovskite framework and exhibit high dispersibility, demonstrating the potential of protonated Sr2IrO4 nanosheets to break the activity-stability trade-off under acidic conditions. Experimental results and theoretical calculations indicate that structural hydroxyl groups on the surface of protonated nanosheets participate in the OER catalytic cycle, significantly enhancing the catalytic activity as illustrated in Fig. 15(g). In addition to protonation treatments, constructing composite structures is also an effective strategy to enhance the performance of Sr2IrO4. Zhang and colleagues created a composite phase by combining SrIrO3 with Sr2IrO4, which regulates Sr leaching in Sr2IrO4 and affects the surface reconstruction of IrO6 octahedra, significantly improving the OER performance of Sr2IrO4 under acidic conditions [145]. Not limited to one-layered Ir-based RP oxide Sr2IrO4, strontium iridates with n >1 were also investigated [49,149]. Recently, Sun and colleagues successfully synthesized a novel RP-structured perovskite oxide Sr4Ir3O10, consisting of alternating SrO rock-salt monolayers and SrIrO3 perovskite multilayers [49]. The unique structure not only promotes efficient interlayer oxygen migration but also enables an interstitial oxygen-assisted LOM process, significantly enhancing OER performance under acidic conditions (Fig. 15h and i). 3.6 Other complex perovskite-derived oxides Apart from the above-mentioned common perovskite oxides, several other low-Ir complex perovskite-derived oxides with unique structures, element compositions, and electronic configurations have been reported as efficient acidic OER electrocatalysts as well, which will be described below. For instance, Zou and colleagues synthesized a novel perovskite oxide 6H-SrIrO3 as a highly active OER electrocatalyst, which exhibits about 7 times higher intrinsic activity than IrO2 but contains 27.1 wt% less Ir [32]. Compared to the conventional 3C-SrIrO3, the Ir–Ir bonds within the face-sharing IrO6 octahedral dimers in 6H-SrIrO3 weaken the binding strength of Ir–O bonds and facilitate the crucial intermediate conversion (i.e., O* → OOH*) during the OER process, thereby significantly improving the acidic OER performance. Later, the same group introduced Co into 6H-SrIrO3, which increases the coverage of hydroxyl groups on the surface, resulting in a threefold increase in mass activity for OER compared with the undoped 6H-SrIrO3 under acidic conditions [150]. In the following study, they further synthesized a metastable strontium iridate with an open-framework structure (i.e., γ-SrIrO3), differing from the structures of α-SrIrO3 (3C-SrIrO3) and β-SrIrO3 (6H-SrIrO3). The structure of γ-SrIrO3 consists of edge-sharing IrO6 octahedral dimers alternately linked via vertex oxygen atoms, creating a three-dimensional open framework (Fig. 16 a) [151]. The unique open framework facilitates rapid proton exchange in acidic media while maintaining its structural integrity, which reconstructs into ultra-small, surface-hydroxylated, (200) oriented IrO2 during acidic OER (Fig. 16b), and accordingly improves the catalytic activity and stability of SrIrO3 (Fig. 16c). Besides, Li and his team reported a novel Ir-based 12L-perovskite (Ba4MIr3O12; M = Pr, Bi, Nb) with trinuclear face-shared octahedral chains, significantly reducing Ir content and enhancing OER performance [152]. Notably, the position of the O 2p-band center can be effectively modulated by adjusting the B-site elements, with Ba2PrIr3O12 demonstrating superior performance. Yang and his colleagues reported another 9R-BaIrO3 perovskite oxide with face-sharing IrO6 octahedral trimers, which is treated with strong acid to remove some Ba atoms, resulting in the formation of 1 nm IrO x particles anchored on 9R-BaIrO3 (IrO x /9R-BaIrO3) (Fig. 16d and e) [38]. The in-situ generation of Ir5+O x species significantly enhances the metallic conductivity of the electrocatalyst, which can facilitate faster charge transfer between the catalyst surface and the electrolyte, thereby contributing to the excellent acidic OER performance of IrO x /9R-BaIrO3 (Fig. 16f). Very recently, Dai et al. reported a novel peroxo-containing La1.2Sr2.7IrO7.33 perovskite oxide with a unique hexagonal structure composed of isolated Ir(V)O6 octahedra and peroxide ions (O2 2−), exhibiting more than ∼6 fold higher intrinsic activity than the benchmark IrO2 but containing 59 wt% less Ir (Fig. 16g and h) [39]. They proposed that La1.2Sr2.7IIrO7.33 catalyzes the OER by POM, which involves the participation of O2 2− as active sites (Fig. 16i). The inherent O2 2− in La1.2Sr2.7IrO7.33 has highly active nonbonded oxygen states, significantly enhancing the catalytic performance in acidic media and resulting in OER activity much higher than that by AEM and LOM. This work firstly provides direct evidence for the participation of peroxide-ion redox chemistry in the acidic OER mechanism of low Ir-based metal oxides, which opens up a new avenue for the design of highly efficient catalysts. 3.7 Practical device applications of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides in PEM water electrolyzers Low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides can significantly reduce the content of noble metals while maintaining electrocatalytic performance, which is crucial for their industrial application [14]. For the device application of PEMWEs, a typical example was reported by Zhao and colleagues, who demonstrated Co-doped SrIrO3 perovskite oxide as a high-performance acidic OER electrocatalyst. When Co-doped SrIrO3 is employed as the anode of PEMWEs, a low potential of 2.0 V is required to achieve a high current density of 1000 mA cm−2. As another example, a PEMWE equipped with Sr2CaIrO6 as an anodic catalyst (low Ir loading: 0.4 mgIr cm−2) achieves 2.40 V at 6 A cm−2 and exhibits no loss in OER performance at a constant 2 A cm−2 [40]. In addition, Yang et al. recently substituted the B-site of BaIrO3 with Co to enhance its activity and durability in PEM water electrolysis, achieving a cell voltage of 1.808 V at 1 A cm−2 with a low Ir content of 0.41 mgIr cm−2 [153]. Despite their promising electrocatalytic OER potential, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides have not been extensively used or adequately explored in PEMWEs, which is attributed to high currents and high temperatures in PEMWEs, imposing greater demands on the electrocatalyst’s activity, proton/electron transfer efficiency, and durability. 3.8 A brief summary This section provides a summary of the various low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for acidic OER electrocatalysis as reported in the literature. These metal oxides possess flexible elemental compositions, unique electronic structures, and stable crystal frameworks for promoting the performance of noble metals. In addition to the inherent advantages of perovskite oxides, their performance can be further enhanced through several design strategies such as ion doping, morphology control, surface reconstruction, defect engineering, phase-structure tuning, hybrid construction, and valence modulation [113,154]. In the field of electrocatalysis, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides show great potential as acidic OER electrocatalysts, primarily due to the following benefits: (1) reducing Ir/Ru content and meanwhile enhancing the electrocatalytic mass activities (Fig. 17 and Table 4 ); (2) maintaining remarkable structural and electrocatalytic stability of Ir/Ru metals within the perovskite oxide lattice; (3) optimizing the use of Ir/Ru with maximized electrocatalytic efficiency for acidic OER. Therefore, the development of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides as high-performance and cost-effective electrocatalysts presents a promising solution to address the issues of traditional IrO2/RuO2 benchmarks with high-content noble metals and poor stability for the applications of acidic OER electrocatalysis. Among the family of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides, single perovskites, double perovskites, and Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites have been widely studied for acidic OER due to their relatively simple structures and excellent capabilities for electronic structure modulation. In contrast, triple perovskites, quadruple perovskites, and other complex perovskite-derived oxides have been less reported because of their complex structures and more stringent synthesis conditions. Notably, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides are seldom reported as OER electrocatalysts in PEM water electrolyzers, which may originate from their tendency to degrade in acidic media, limiting their potential for commercialization in practical applications [18]. Therefore, the degradation mechanisms of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides under acidic OER require to be carefully investigated. Ru-based electrocatalysts are recognized to be highly unstable under harsh acidic conditions, with metal Ru undergoing almost transient dissolution during acidic OER. Compared to metallic Ru, low-Ru perovskite oxides exhibit greater stability but remain highly susceptible to dissolution into RuO4 at high potentials (>1.4 V) [112]. Therefore, the conversion of Ru4+ to Ru>4+ is deemed to be the major origin of the degradation of Ru-based perovskite oxides during acidic OER. The degradation of Ir-based perovskite oxides is generally less severe than that of Ru-based perovskite oxides, but structural collapse remains a major problem, which is primarily caused by metal leaching from the electrocatalysts [75]. With the continuous advancement of electrocatalyst design strategies, it is anticipated that more advanced low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides will be developed, driving further progress in the acidic OER. 4 Conclusions and perspectives Over the past few years, significant breakthroughs have been made in developing low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides towards efficient OER electrocatalysis in acidic media. In this review, we briefly discussed the general issues relevant to acidic OER catalyzed by low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides, such as the catalytic active species, OER mechanisms, inverse activity-stability relationship, and performance evaluation metrics. In addition, a comprehensive overview of recent advances in low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides reported as acidic OER electrocatalysts is provided, including single perovskites, double perovskites, triple perovskites, quadruple perovskites, Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites, and other complex perovskite-derived oxides, with focus on the intrinsic factors contributing to their remarkable electrocatalytic performance. Despite impressive progress in developing low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for efficient acidic OER, several challenges remain at the current stage. From our perspective, future research in this field could prioritize the following areas, as illustrated in Fig. 18 . 4.1 Exploiting new functional materials and synthesis methods Despite significant progress in the development of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for acidic OER, the content of noble metals remains relatively high. However, noble-metal-based perovskite oxides continue to exhibit unparalleled OER activity in comparison to noble-metal-free perovskite oxides, which is due to the poor stability of noble-metal-free perovskite oxides in acidic media [26]. Triple perovskite, quadruple perovskite, and other complex perovskite-derived oxides exhibit distinct advantages in further reducing noble metal content and realizing ideal activity and stability [22,30,155]. Nevertheless, research on these oxides remains very limited due to their more stringent synthesis conditions. As discussed above, the connectivity of subunits in complex perovskite oxides significantly influences the adsorption behavior of reaction intermediates, thereby impacting catalytic performance [32,151,152]. Currently, there is a lack of systematic studies on the factors governing subunit connectivity. Therefore, developing simple and universal synthesis methods for such complex perovskite oxides represents a critical direction for future research. The same perovskite oxide synthesized by different methods may exhibit different properties and catalytic performance [102]. Some low-temperature synthesis methods, such as sol-gel, co-precipitation, and hydrothermal/solvothermal, can synthesize perovskite oxides with small particle sizes and high surface areas, typically demonstrating higher activity and stability [156]. In addition, Joule heating (JH), an ultrafast thermal method, which can reach an ultrahigh temperature (>3000 K) within milliseconds, has been widely employed in the synthesis of complex materials. The extremely short heating time of the JH method not only prevents the agglomeration of active species but also promotes the dispersion of active atoms, consequently leading to higher electrochemical performance [157]. Recently, some advancements in computational technologies, such as machine learning, high-throughput computing, and artificial intelligence, have garnered significant attention in electrocatalysis [158–160]. Specifically, machine learning can predict electrocatalytic performance based on existing data, accelerate the discovery of new catalysts, and substantially reduce trial-and-error processes. For instance, Sun and colleagues systematically designed a series of perovskite oxides with 20 consistent parameters, using Bayesian-optimized symbolic regression to identify catalytic activity descriptors. The model enables the screening of 177,100 compositions, among which (Pr0.05La0.4Nd0.2Sm0.1Y0.25)BaCo2O5+ δ exhibits the highest OER performance [161]. Moving forward, integrating computational technologies with novel synthesis methods to optimize the design and preparation of complex low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides is highly desirable. 4.2 Establishing more accurate structure-property-performance relationship In acidic OER processes, dynamic structural changes in low Ir/Ru-based perovskite oxides are inevitable, resulting in a distinction between the initial material and the real active species, which complicates the understanding of the interrelationships among structure, property, and performance [162,163]. A thorough understanding of the true active sites in catalysts under operational conditions is essential for uncovering their intrinsic catalytic mechanisms. While ex-situ characterization provides fundamental insights into the catalysts after the OER reaction, the effectiveness is limited by unavoidable air exposure before the catalysts are transferred into vacuum apparatuses, which may distort the identification of active species. Additionally, relying on post-reaction states fails to capture the reversible structural changes that active sites undergo during OER. Therefore, it is crucial to understand the transient changes that occur when voltage is applied. Under these dynamic conditions, in-situ/operando characterization techniques are regarded as essential tools as they enable real-time monitoring of structural transformations and the evolution of reaction intermediates. Current in-situ/operando characterization techniques such as Raman, TEM, XRD, XPS, FTIR, DEMS, SECM, XAS, and Mӧssbauer spectroscopy are employed to gather structural and intermediate information, but they often output weak signal [63–65]. However, the rapid structural reconstructions occurring within picoseconds to nanoseconds pose a significant challenge for current technologies to capture. To precisely capture the instantaneous structural changes and dynamic adsorption/desorption processes at active sites, two approaches are recommended as follows. (1) Improving the temporal and spatial resolutions of optical and spectroscopic instruments. Current in-situ/operando measurements typically require a certain period of time to collect the results. For instance, collecting an XAS or XRD spectrum takes several minutes. However, the lifetime of reaction intermediates is often on the picosecond scale, and the catalyst may undergo significant and irreversible changes during the time to collect on the spectrum. Further advancement, for instance developing fast scan technologies and utilizing high-energy X-rays, could enable the collection of XRD or XAS patterns within seconds. Additionally, high spatial resolution and energy resolution will benefit the capturing of the subtle dynamic evolution of catalysts. (2) Integrating multiple in-situ/operando techniques. Each individual in-situ/operando technique provides limited insight into the catalytic reaction from a specific perspective, combining multiple in-situ/operando characterizations is essential for obtaining a more comprehensive understanding of the catalytic process. For example, the integration of in-situ/operando FTIR and Raman in the same reaction cell using synchrotron light sources will enable the simultaneous detection of both catalyst structural changes and reaction intermediate evolution during the OER. The combination of multiple in-situ/operando characterizations can enable a more convincing mechanism study at the same temporal and spatial scale. Understanding the relationship between structure, property, and performance is essential for designing efficient electrocatalysts for the acidic OER. During the OER electrocatalytic process, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides inevitably undergo dynamic structural changes, complicating the accurate determination of the structure-property-performance relationships [26,164]. Some studies demonstrate that the involvement of lattice oxygen in LOM accompanied by the generation of oxygen vacancies on the surface is the incentive factor for structural collapse [22,165]. Therefore, it is essential to design low-Ir/Ru perovskite structures that are capable of tolerating oxygen vacancies and improving the adsorption and replenishment rates of hydroxy groups, which can break the scaling relationship among various intermediates in AEM and prevent the structural change in LOM. Although acidic OER is a complex reaction process involving four-electron transfers, researchers still find some quantitative indicators to correlate the electrocatalysts’ structure with activity and stability [166]. For instance, the O 2p-band center in perovskite oxides is a well-known descriptor, which can be altered by a few structural changes such as the substitution of different alkaline-earth A-site elements [94]. When the O 2p-band center gets closer to the Fermi level, the electrocatalytic activity will improve while the stability of electrocatalysts will worsen. Therefore, the balance of stability and activity of perovskite oxides requires a moderate O 2p-band center position, which can be realized by the rational structure design of perovskite oxides. Most indicators, with a few exceptions, fail to correlate the structure with both electrocatalytic stability and activity, limiting their ability to predict high-performance electrocatalysts more accurately. Therefore, there is an urgent necessity to develop some more quantifiable and predictable descriptors to provide an accurate expression of structure-property-performance relationships. Significantly, with the help of artificial intelligence, some descriptors have identified some electrocatalysts’ structures with high theoretical electrochemical activity and stability [158]. For example, Grzybowski et al. integrated closed-loop experiments with data-driven machine learning, facilitating the design of a perovskite oxide electrocatalyst with exceptional OER performance [167]. 4.3 Dedicating practical PEMWE applications Low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides can effectively reduce the use of noble metals while maintaining both electrocatalytic activity and stability, which is crucial for their industrial application [14]. For example, Co-doped SrIrO3 demonstrates high durability with a performance degradation rate of 0.21 mV h−1 during the long-term tests in PEM water electrolysis [110]. Despite the significant potential of Ir/Ru-based perovskite oxides, they have not been fully used or adequately explored in practical device applications. Compared to the conventional three-electrode system tests in laboratories, the operating environment of PEM electrolysis cells is characterized by high currents and high temperatures, which impose greater demands on the catalyst’s activity, proton/electron transfer efficiency, and stability [14,74,168]. Therefore, integrating low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides into membrane electrode assemblies and conducting thorough performance evaluations is very significant. However, the relatively large particle size of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides often leads to the generation of settling during the electrode coating process, resulting in uneven catalyst distribution. Non-uniform electrode preparation can significantly compromise the performance of low-noble-metal electrocatalysts. Furthermore, perovskite oxides generally suffer from poor electrical conductivity, necessitating the addition of carbon black to improve charge transfer. However, under long-term and high-current operations in practical applications, carbon black is often prone to be oxidized, inevitably degrading the performance of the catalyst. To address these challenges, future research should focus on optimizing the ink formulations and improving the ultrasonic spray deposition techniques to minimize the catalyst’s settling. Additionally, enhancing the intrinsic conductivity of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides is also critical to maximizing catalytic activity and reducing external resistance. In conclusion, low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for acidic OER have made significant progress in recent years, and the expectations surrounding them continue to rise. Despite the above-mentioned challenges ahead, we are looking forward to great progress in this appealing field by tuning rich compositional and structural chemistries of low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides. Lingjie Yuan is currently pursuing her Ph.D. degree under the supervision of Prof. Yinlong Zhu at the University of Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics. Her current research focuses on the development of perovskite oxides for oxygen and hydrogen electrocatalysis. Yinlong Zhu received his PhD degree from the College of Chemical Engineering at Nanjing Tech University in 2017 and then worked as a Discovery Early Career Researcher Award (DECRA) Fellow at Monash University, Australia (2017.12–2021/12), and a professor at Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (2022.1–present). His current research focuses on the development of functional materials as high-performance electrocatalysts for the application of electrochemical energy conversion and storage technologies, such as fuel cells, metal-air batteries, water splitting, and electrolyzers.

coredata.dc:description: Proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer (PEMWE) represents a highly promising technology for renewable hydrogen generation, urgently demanding low-cost, efficient, and robust anode oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalysts in acidic media. Over the past decade (mainly from 2016 onwards), low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides have emerged as promising candidate materials for acidic OER electrocatalysis owing to their flexible element compositions and crystal structures, which can evidently reduce the noble-metal content and meanwhile significantly promote electrocatalytic performance. In this review, the current research progress in low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for acidic OER electrocatalysis is comprehensively summarized. Initially, we present a brief introduction to general issues relevant to acidic OER catalyzed by low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides, such as the actual active species, OER mechanisms, inverse activity-stability relationship, and performance evaluation metrics. Subsequently, we present a thorough overview of various low-Ir/Ru perovskite oxides for acidic OER electrocatalysis, including single perovskites, double perovskites, triple perovskites, quadruple perovskites, Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites, and other complex perovskite-derived oxides, with emphasis on the intrinsic factors contributing to their exceptional performance and structure–property-performance correlation. Finally, remaining challenges and some promising insights to inspire future studies in this exciting field are provided.
